The traceability of groundwater nitrate pollution is crucial for controlling and managing polluted groundwater. This study integrates hydrochemistry, nitrate isotope (5‘°N-NO;- and 5*8O-NO,°), and self-organizing map (SOM) and end-member mixing (EMMTE) models to identify the sources and quantify the contributions of nitrate pollution to groundwater in an intensive agricultural region in the Sha River Basin in southwestern Henan Province. The results indicate that the NO;--N concentration in 74% (n = 39) of the groundwater samples exceeded the WHO standard of 10 mg/L. According to the results of EMMTE modeling, soil nitrogen (68.4%) was the main source of nitrate in Cluster-1, followed by manure and sewage (16.5%), chemical fertilizer (11.9%) and atmospheric deposition (3.3%). In Cluster-2, soil nitrogen (60.1%) was the main source of nitrate, with a significant increase in the contribution of manure and sewage (35.5%). The considerable contributions of soil nitrogen may be attributed to the high nitrogen fertilizer usage that accumulated in the soil in this traditional agricultural area. Moreover, it is apparent that most Cluster-2 sampling sites with high contributions of manure and sewage are located around residential land. Therefore, the arbitrary discharge and leaching of domestic sewage may be responsible for these results. Therefore, this study provides useful assistance for the continuous management and pollution control of groundwater in the Sha River Basin. Groundwater, a vital freshwater resource, is crucial for human consumption and human production activities. In China, over 400 cities and the majority of rural areas rely on groundwater as their drinking water source’. However, the rapid modernization of agriculture is increasingly leading to groundwater pollution. For instance, fertilizer usage in China increased from 133.49 x 10° tons in 1981 to 519.1 x 10° tons in 2021. The excessive use of chemical fertilizers is primarily responsible for regional nitrogen increases, which significantly threaten the water environment**. Among nitrogen compounds, NO, is highly mobile and soluble and easily contaminates groundwater by leaching. Once in the aquifer, NO,” can stabilize in an oxidizing environment, accumulating over decades*®. Identifying nitrate sources is thus critical for effective groundwater pollution management. Accurately identifying and quantifying NO; sources is essential for mitigating the damage caused by this pollution. NO; pollution originates from many sources, including domestic sewage, industrial wastewater, fertilizers and manure from agricultural activities, atmospheric precipitation and soil organic nitrogen*”'°. Different NO; sources have unique isotopic signatures; therefore, dual nitrate isotope methods have been widely applied to assess NO; sources and reveal the mechanisms of nitrogen transport transformation in surface water and groundwater'' |”. However, challenges in NO;~ traceability arise from overlapping isotopic signatures and isotopic fractionation during the nitrogen cycle (e.g., nitrification, denitrification, ammonification, volatilization)'*'*. To overcome these limitations, studies have combined nitrate isotopes with hydrochemistry data (e.g., Cl, Na)'°, other isotopes (e.g., 6''B, ®’Sr/**Sr, 5'°N-NH,*, A’’O-NO,; )'*'S, multivariate statistical methods”, and microbiological methods”®”'. This integrated methodology offers a more comprehensive and accurate means of identifying nitrate sources, thereby deepening our understanding of their origins. A variety of methods, including scatter plots and multivariate statistics, have been extensively used to characterize nitrate pollution in groundwater. However, due to their nonlinearity and high dispersion, groundwater hydrochemistry data often result in misinterpretations when analyzed with traditional linear methods such as factor and principal component analysis, which struggle with nonlinearity and nonsmoothness~”*. Therefore, these traditional analysis methods fall short of meeting current research needs. In contrast, a self-organizing map (SOM), an unsupervised neural network model, effectively maps complex nonlinear data into two dimensions, enabling systematic analysis and revealing local intervariable relationships”. Moreover, EMMTE, a new tool for stable isotope analysis of nitrate sources, outperforms conventional MixSIAR, offering higher prediction accuracy, lower root mean square error (RMSE), and reduced relative bias”. Combining EMMTEs with SOM facilitates the shift from qualitative to quantitative analysis, enhancing the understanding and interpretation of groundwater nitrate sources and transformation processes.

The Sha River Basin, which is part of the Huai River Basin in Henan Province, is a significant agricultural area. Extensive research indicates significant shallow groundwater pollution in this region****. However, previous studies have mostly focused on the middle and lower reaches of the Huai River Basin, with limited attention given to the upper reaches, primarily involving qualitative analyses of nitrate pollution and its spatial distribution. Nitrate isotope analysis, which can reveal the sources and contributions of nitrates in this area, has been underutilized. This study aims to identify the sources and quantify the contributions of groundwater pollution by integrating groundwater hydrochemical data and water and nitrate isotope measurements with SOM and EMMTE modeling. This comprehensive approach will systematically explore the sources and evolution of nitrates, providing a detailed and thorough perspective on nitrate pollution, which is crucial for developing effective strategies to mitigate its environmental impact. The objectives of this study are to (1) identify the primary sources and transformation processes of NO; in groundwater, (2) quantify the contribution of each NO; source using the EMMTE model, and (3) make reasonable recommendations for watershed management and protection based on the identified pollution sources. The map of the groundwater data acquired via SOM training on a Chadha diagram (Fig. 4) reveals that the majority of the samples in the study area are categorized as recharge water. In Cluster 1, 91% (n= 11) and in Cluster 2, 78% (n=21) of the water samples are of the HCO3-Ca-Mg type, which is indicative of recharge water. The present study suggested that the elevated Na concentration might result from sewage infiltration, as Cluster-2 represents high-concentration NO; -N groundwater, which may promote this reverse exchange process**.

The EMMTE model employs 5'°N-NO; and 8'8O-NO,_ as tracers to quantify contributions from various nitrate sources. Combined with the analysis of possible nitrate sources in our study and previous references, atmospheric deposition (AD), soil nitrogen (SON), chemical fertilizer (CF), and manure and sewage (M&S) were used as potential nitrate sources in this study. The means and standard deviations of !°N-NO;” and 5'80-NO,° for each source are shown in Table 4. The AD and M&S values were measured in the lower reaches of the Sha River, the CF values were measured in the Nanyang Plain, and the SON values were measured in the North China Plain. The reason for selecting these references in this study is primarily due to the similarity and proximity of the climate and farming practices in the reference areas to our study area. Since denitrification does not occur in groundwater, the fractionation factor C= 0 is used to calculate the nitrate contribution rate of the EMMTE model. The EMMTE model output (Fig. 11) reveals differences in nitrate source contributions between Cluster-1 and Cluster-2. In Cluster-1, the contributions from potential nitrate sources were SON (68.4%), M&S (16.5%), CF (11.9%), and AD (3.3%). In Cluster-2, the contributions were SON (60.1%), M&S (35.5%), CF (3.2%), and AD (1.2%). In both Cluster-1 and Cluster-2, AD contributed minimally, which is consistent with the results in Fig. 10, where no samples fell within the atmospheric deposition zone. According to previous studies, atmospheric nitrogen deposition (TN) in the area ranges from 17.6 to 22.8 kg N/ha year*!. This low AD impact is likely due to microbial nitrification altering most of the AD in soil before it enters the water environment. Therefore, the contribution of AD was very limited”. As a traditional agricultural area, the study region has high nitrogen fertilizer usage, approximately 190 kg N/ha (data from http://www.pds.gov.cn/). In agricultural production, nitrogen fertilizer not absorbed by crops, along with accumulated soil nitrogen, gradually leaches into the groundwater system. Hence, it is unsurprising that considerable NO” loads in Cluster-1 and Cluster-2 (68.2% and 60.3%, respectively) are attributed to soil nitrogen. Notably, in Cluster-2, the contribution from CFs decreases by 8.7%, while M&S contributions increase to second place. This suggests that M&S was the main contributor to the high nitrate concentration in Cluster-2 within the same soil context. The EMMTE model used in this study is a random statistical variable model, so the contribution estimates for each source are part of a probability distribution with uncertainty. To analyze the uncertainty in the distribution of nitrate sources, we used an uncertainty index (Ulg9)°. Ugg denotes the difference in the proportional contribution between the 5% and 95% quantiles divided by 0.9 (see detailed information in Wang et al. (2023))!°. The Ulsy index reflects the range of uncertainty in the contribution rate, with higher Ulsy values indicating greater uncertainty in the contribution rate. The results shown in Fig. 12 indicate that AD has the smallest uncertainty in both Cluster-1 and Cluster-2 (UI90 = 0.03, 0.10), suggesting that its contribution is stable with minimal spatial-temporal variation. In Cluster-1, SON has the highest uncertainty (UI90 = 0.67), followed by M&S (UI90 = 0.49) and CF (UI90 = 0.34). In Cluster-2, SON (UI90 = 0.62) shows the highest uncertainty, closely followed by M&S (UI90=0.61). The increased uncertainties in SON and M&S are likely due to the spatial and temporal variability in their isotopic compositions. For example, increased precipitation during the rainy season causes fluctuations in the water table, which alters the redox environment of the soil and groundwater and affects the nitrogen cycle (e.g., nitrification, denitrification, nitrate reduction, etc.). This leads to isotopic fractionation and increasing uncertainty in NO; sources. The high uncertainty in the EMMTE distribution results is unavoidable, stemming from the broad range of potential source proportions, large standard deviations, limited sample size, and absence of field measurements of pollution source isotopes in the study area. Despite this uncertainty, M&S inputs are identified as the main contributors to high nitrate levels; therefore, the improvement and refinement of rural wastewater treatment facilities is a key factor in controlling nitrate pollution in the Sha River Basin. Additionally, to enhance nitrate traceability analysis accuracy, further isotopic measurements of nitrate sources and determination of isotopic fractionation factors during the nitrogen cycle in the study area are needed.

This study employed SOM clustering to downscale and cluster groundwater hydrochemistry indicators in the Sha River Basin. Chadha and Gibbs plots were used to illustrate the hydrochemistry of these clusters. Water isotopes were utilized to ascertain the groundwater source, along with its recharge and discharge conditions. In addition, the distribution, source, transformation and contribution of nitrate in the groundwater system were analyzed using isotope data and the EMMTE model. The results show that the SOM classified 11 hydrochemistry parameters into two clusters, which paired with Chadha plots indicating that the dominant hydrochemistry phases were HCO,-Ca—Mg and Ca—Mg-Cl. The Gibbs plots suggest that rock weathering is the dominant process influencing groundwater hydrochemistry in both clusters. The 5D-H,O and 6'8O-H,O compositions reveal that the groundwater predominantly originates from recent precipitation, with minimal changes due to evaporation. Nitrate isotope analysis indicated that 74% of the groundwater NO,-N content exceeded the national Class III standard limit (20 mg/L). In both Cluster-1 and Cluster-2, denitrification was absent, and nitrification was the primary nitrogen cycle process. According to the results of EMMTE modeling, SON was the main source of nitrate in Cluster-1, followed by M&S, CE, and AD; in Cluster-2, SON was still the main source of nitrate, with significant increase in the contribution of M&S, suggesting that anthropogenic activities are the main cause of nitrate contamination. Given that SON and M&S are the main NO; sources in the groundwater around the Sha River, implementing effective farming practices, enhancing fertilizer use efficiency, improving rural sewage treatment facilities, and uniformly collecting and treating sewage and manure are important ways to reduce NO; pollution in aquifers in watersheds. In this study, by combining SOM modeling and isotope data, we revealed the natural and anthropogenic sources of nitrate, which provides useful information for the continuous management and pollution control of groundwater in the Sha River Basin. The study area, which is situated at 112° 50'-113° 15’ E, 33° 50’-35° 40'N, is in southwestern Henan Province, upstream of the Huai River Basin (Fig. 13). The area falls within the temperate continental monsoon climate zone and is characterized by distinct dry and wet seasons. The average annual temperature is 14.9 °C, ranging from a minimum of 1.2 °C in January to a maximum of 27.6 °C in August. The annual rainfall varies between 373.9 and 1361.9 mm, with 70-80% occurring between June and September (data from http://www.weather.com.cn/). The predominant soil types are deep-layered alluvial soils, primarily silty loam in texture. The main land use in the study area is agriculture”. The land use type is dominated by arable land with a cultivated area of approximately 446 kha and fertilizer application of 727 kg/ha. The main food crops include wheat and corn, while the cash crops include cotton, peanuts, rapeseed, and tobacco (data from http://www.pds. gov.cn/). The groundwater in the study area is categorized into four groups: loose rock pore water, carbonate rock fissure karst water, clastic rock fissure pore water and bedrock fissure water. Groundwater recharge primarily occurs through atmospheric precipitation, surface water, and irrigation, while discharge occurs via vertical evaporation, artificial extraction, and lateral runoff’. Field investigations and sampling were conducted in the Sha River basin in August 2021 (Fig. 1). A total of 39 samples were collected from shallow groundwater for geochemical analyses, including in situ physicochemical parameters, major ions and trace elements, along with stable isotope measurements of water and nitrate. All the wells chosen for sampling served domestic and agricultural purposes. The groundwater was pumped before sampling until the physicochemical parameters stabilized. The samples were then stored in high-density polyethylene bottles: one 1.0 L bottle for major ion analysis and four 100 mL bottles for trace element and isotope analysis. On the day of sampling, two samples were filtered through a 0.22 um membrane for stable isotope analysis. For trace element analysis, two samples were filtered through a 0.45 um membrane, with one acidified using HNO,. All the samples were refrigerated at 4 °C until analysis.

The pH, electrical conductivity (EC), water temperature (Tw), total dissolved solids (TDS) and redox potential (ORP) of the water were measured in situ using a portable meter (Kedida CT6021A, China) and (Hanna HI98130, Italy) with detection limit of 0.1 mg/L. Cations such as K*, Ca”, Na*, Mg”*, Fe and Mn were analyzed using inductively coupled plasma (ICP) emission spectrometry (Optima 7000, USA) with an analytical uncertainly of + 1%. Bicarbonate concentrations were determined through acid—base titration. Anions, including F-, NO,, NO; and SO,”, were analyzed by an ion chromatography instrument (MIC 7, Merton, Switzerland) with an analytical uncertainly of + 1%. The above experiments were completed at the Henan Key Laboratory of Water Pollution Control and Rehabilitation. Water isotopes (SD-H,O and 5!8O-H,O) were measured using an isotope ratio mass spectrometer (Finnigan MAT Delta S, Thermo Fisher, USA). The self-organizing map (SOM), which is an unsupervised artificial neural network model, was proposed by*. SOM can map high-latitude raw data to a two-dimensional plan preserving the topology of the raw data and the stability of the metric relations, which makes it ideal for nonlinear dimensionality reduction and unsupervised classification’. The main considerations for developing an SOM include its structural design, training algorithm and neighborhood kernel function****. The quantization error (QE) and terrain error (TE) are used to evaluate the selection of map nodes and the optimal number of nodes**”*. Since the SOM cannot automatically determine the optimal number of clusters, the K-means algorithm is employed to classify the transition boundaries and clusters of the output units. The optimal number of clusters is determined by the the minimum Davies-Bouldin (DBI) value*’. where C;+ Gis the sum of the mean distances from all points to the centroid point of the cluster, and d(C, CG) is the distance between the centroid points of clusters i and j. Lower DBI values indicate that the data are well clustered, with points in each cluster similar to each other but distinct from points in other clusters****. Thus, the minimum DBI of the k-means algorithm is the basis for determining the optimal number of clusters. The present study implemented the SOM algorithm in R (package ‘aweSOM’).
